unnormalised: ## Decoding Rental Yields: Are You Actually Making Money, Yaar?
normalised: ## Decoding Rental Yields: Are You Actually Making Money, Yaar?

unnormalised: So, you’ve finally bought that 2BHK in Bandra you've been eyeing, imagining yourself swimming in passive income? Hold your horses, buddy! Just owning property doesn't guarantee you're rolling in dough. That's where rental yield comes in. Think of it as your property's financial report card, telling you how efficiently it’s generating income.
normalised: So, you’ve finally bought that two B H K in Bandra you've been eyeing, imagining yourself swimming in passive income? Hold your horses, buddy! Just owning property doesn't guarantee you're rolling in dough. That's where rental yield comes in. Think of it as your property's financial report card, telling you how efficiently it’s generating income.

unnormalised: Basically, rental yield is the return on investment (ROI) you're getting from renting out your property. It's usually expressed as a percentage. A higher yield means more moolah in your pocket.
normalised: Basically, rental yield is the return on investment (R O I) you're getting from renting out your property. It's usually expressed as a percentage. A higher yield means more moolah in your pocket.

unnormalised: Annual Rental Income / Property Value x 100
normalised: Annual Rental Income divided by Property Value multiplied by one hundred

unnormalised: Let's say Mrs. Sharma rents out her 1000 sq ft apartment in Powai for Rs. 30,000 a month (Rs. 3,60,000 annually). The property value is, say, Rs. 90,00,000.
normalised: Let's say Mistress Sharma rents out her one thousand square feet apartment in Powai for rupees thirty thousand a month (rupees three lakh sixty thousand annually). The property value is, say, rupees ninety lakh.
Rental Yield = (three lakh sixty thousand divided by ninety lakh) multiplied by one hundred = four percent

unnormalised: So, Mrs. Sharma is getting a 4% rental yield.
normalised: So, Mistress Sharma is getting a four percent rental yield.
**Is four percent Good? Not Always, Boss!**

unnormalised: A "good" rental yield depends on a lot of factors: location (South Bombay will likely have lower yields than Navi Mumbai due to higher property prices), property type, market conditions, and even the condition of your property. Dr. Reddy, a real estate analyst from IIM Bangalore, often mentions that anything above 5% is generally considered good in Indian metro cities.
normalised: A "good" rental yield depends on a lot of factors: location (South Bombay will likely have lower yields than Navi Mumbai due to higher property prices), property type, market conditions, and even the condition of your property. Doctor Reddy, a real estate analyst from I I M Bangalore, often mentions that anything above five percent is generally considered good in Indian metro cities.

unnormalised: Don't forget to factor in expenses! Property tax, maintenance charges, society fees, and potential repairs (that leaky faucet ain't gonna fix itself!) will eat into your profits.
normalised: Don't forget to factor in expenses! Property tax, maintenance charges, society fees, and potential repairs (that leaky faucet ain't gonna fix itself!) will eat into your profits.

unnormalised: Before you take the plunge into property investment, do your homework, understand rental yields, and factor in all those hidden costs. Otherwise, you might end up with a beautiful apartment... and an empty wallet. Jai Hind!
